question_text: A 34-year-old patient presents with a rash that developed 6 months ago after being diagnosed with HIV infection. The patient is currently untreated for both the rash and HIV.Skin findings on the arm are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The mostly likely diagnosis is psoriasis (Option C). This patient presents with red, sharply marginated plaques with silver-white adherent and lamellar (sheet-like) scale on the extensor arm and elbow. These are the classic findings of psoriasis vulgaris, or plaque psoriasis. Psoriasis may also be associated with a number of systemic conditions, including metabolic disorders, such as metabolic hepatosteatosis, diabetes mellitus, and the metabolic syndrome; inflammatory bowel syndrome; celiac disease; uveitis; and spondyloarthritis. Psoriasis is a common chronic skin condition, but appears more commonly in patients with HIV infection and may appear around the time of initial infection.In contrast, dermatitis and secondary syphilis have a more granular or flaky scale, compared with the flat sheet-like scale of psoriasis. Kaposi sarcoma presents as dark red, brown, or violaceous lesions of the skin or mucous membranes; it is caused by human herpesvirus 8 and is often seen in patients with HIV infection.
